title: Energy, Impulse, and Stability of Thin Vortex Loops in Incompressible, Inviscid Fluids
description: This article reviews and systematizes classical results on thin vortex rings and closed vortex loops in incompressible, inviscid fluids, emphasizing their finite energy, impulse, and effective “particle-like” properties. For a thin circular vortex ring of radius \( R \), core radius \( a \ll R \), circulation \( \Gamma \), and density \( \rho \), we summarize standard expressions for kinetic energy, hydrodynamic impulse, and self-induced translational speed: \( E = \tfrac{1}{2}\rho \Gamma^2 R (\ln(8R/a) - \alpha) \), \( \bm{I} = \rho \pi \Gamma R^2 \hat{\bm{z}} \), and \( U = \Gamma [\ln(8R/a) - \beta]/(4\pi R) \), with model-dependent constants \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \). We then define an effective mass \( M_{\mathrm{eff}} = \|\bm{I}\|/U \), which encodes the ring’s particle-like behavior as a localized object with finite energy and momentum. The paper discusses curvature and pressure-gradient balance in the Euler equations, the role of Kelvin waves and instabilities, and extends the analysis to general and knotted vortex loops using the Biot–Savart representation and helicity \( H = \int \boldsymbol{v}\cdot\boldsymbol{\omega}\,\mathrm{d}V \). Knotted filaments carry finite energy and conserved helicity expressed in terms of linking and self-linking numbers, highlighting how closed and knotted vortex loops function as robust, finite-energy bound configurations in classical vortex dynamics, without invoking any speculative extensions of fluid theory.
